fringe noun [C]
(MINORITY)
a part of a group that is not very powerful, or is more extreme than the main group, and does not include many of its members : the radical fringes of the partylunatic fringe The pamphlet was generally dismissed as the work of a small lunatic fringe.fringe meeting He attended several of the fringe meetings at the conference.fringe candidate She's a fringe candidate who has no real chance of getting elected.

fringe noun [C]
(GOLF)
in golf, an area surrounding the green where the grass is longer than the grass on the green but shorter than the grass on the fairway : As she walked up to the green to survey her next shot, the ball began to roll down to the fringe. Fans loudly applauded his 30-foot putt across the green from the fringe.
More examplesFewer examplesHe came up well short on his third shot, the ball stopping on the front fringe.Only the putting surfaces on the greens and the fringe remain green, while the fairways are brown.He needed to hit the ball hard enough to cross the fringe and yet softly enough for it not to roll miles past the pin.
